Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantum cascade laser sources of high-power, coherent frequency combs

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract title: Compact, high-power semiconductor laser sources of coherent frequency combs for fast and efficient molecular detection

Abstract:
Non-technical: The objective of the project is the development of compact, practical, high-power semiconductor laser sources of coherent frequency combs in the mid-infrared spectral range. The combs work as rulers in frequency space, providing fast and accurate readings of frequencies of molecular vibrations. These frequencies can serve as unique identifiers of different molecules. Therefore, the proposed laser sources will enable ultra-broadband and fast molecular spectroscopy, which has a wide range of applications in trace gas environmental monitoring, pharmaceutical quality control and remote detection of biochemical agents. The project will explore a new mechanism of frequency comb generation, which is based on coherent pulsations in quantum cascade lasers. The project will be pursued as a collaborative effort between the team members at Harvard and Texas A&M University and in collaboration with world-leading spectroscopy experts from Europe. This will create unique inter-disciplinary and multi-cultural education, research, and outreach opportunities for all involved students and researchers.

Technical: The objective of this collaborative research is to develop high-power semiconductor laser sources of coherent frequency combs in the mid-infrared based on continuously pumped quantum cascade lasers. The field of quantum cascade laser mode locking and frequency combs has seen rapid expansion over the last three years, due to contributions of the proposing team and several other groups. However, so far broadband phase-coherent combs have been demonstrated in lasers of special design in a narrow interval of currents near threshold. Ultrafast gain relaxation presents a fundamental obstacle to most mode locking techniques. The proposing team will focus on a new route to frequency combs through coherent Rabi oscillations, which result in parametric generation of a phase-coherent "supercomb" of modes separated by terahertz frequency intervals. The resulting harmonic mode locking is equivalent in time domain to amplitude modulation at terahertz frequencies comparable to the gain relaxation rate. This new mechanism of frequency comb generation is entirely phase-coherent and intrinsically operates high enough above threshold, yielding high power per mode. The project will pursue several strategies of utilizing the Rabi mechanism for generation of stable, high-power, and broadband combs using standard high-performance laser chips.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People are used to think of a laser as a source of intense, single-color (monochromatic) beam of light. However, a laser can also be forced to operate in a pulsed regime, when an ultrashort pulse of light is bouncing back and forth between semi-transparent laser cavity mirrors, emitting an outburst of radiation at every bounce. The resulting laser output is a comb of many (from hundreds to many thousands) monochromatic modes, separated by a low frequency inversely proportional to the round-trip time of light in a laser cavity. This intermodal separation is typically in the radio frequency range from Megahertz to Gigahertz (GHz). Such a regime is called laser frequency combs. Frequency combs provide direct link between optical and radio frequencies, enabling high-precision measurements of the optical frequencies for numerous applications in sensing and telecommunications. That is why the 2005 Nobel Prize in physics was awarded to John Hall and Ted Haensch for realization of frequency combs in the visible and near-infrared spectra.

The next frontier in frequency comb technology is the mid-infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum. This is where all molecules have their tell-tale absorption and emission spectral lines, while at the same time the Earth atmosphere has the spectral windows of almost total transparency. This makes conquering this region vital for applications ranging from medical diagnostics, environmental and industrial monitoring, and climate change monitoring to free-space telecommunications. The dominant type of mid-infrared semiconductor lasers needed to operate in this region is so-called quantum cascade lasers (QCLs). However, QCLs do not operate in a pulsed regime which makes generation of frequency combs a fundamental challenge.

One important outcome of this project is the design and demonstration of QCLs that do generate frequency combs despite the fact that their light output is maintained at nearly constant intensity. The physical mechanism of the frequency comb generation in this case is the nonlinear interaction of monochromatic laser light with the quantum-well active region of a laser, which leads to frequency modulation of laser radiation and oscillations of electrons trapped in semiconductor quantum wells. As a result, multiple frequencies get generated and phase-locked together, forming a frequency comb. The project demonstrated the way to achieve robust, high-power frequency comb operation of standard commercial QCLs.

The second key outcome of the project is the discovery of a new frequency comb regime, so-called harmonic state, in which the separation between neighboring modes (?teeth?) of the comb can be much larger than the typical 5-7 GHz distance determined by the laser length. Lasers developed in the project routinely demonstrated comb spacings of hundreds to thousands of GHz, thus establishing the link to the terahertz (THz) spectral region which remains perhaps the most under-developed part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

Moreover, the project established multiple ways to control the comb spacing in QCLs from several GHz to more than 1 THz. This enables generation and detection of THz signals in chip-scale devices, which paves the way to such applications as compact THz sensors for homeland security and biomedical sciences, transceivers for free-space THz communications, and terabit-scale information processing.

The project has resulted in training of highly skilled workforce involved in research at TAMU and Harvard sites. The project results have been disseminated through high-profile papers, undergraduate and graduate courses at TAMU and Harvard, the REU program, numerous conference presentations, tutorial lectures and public talks, press releases, and multi-pronged outreach activities: Texas A&M Physics and Engineering festivals, summer schools for high-school physics teachers, Society of Physics Students presentations, etc. Mutually beneficial international collaborations between project participants and leading groups in Europe and Japan have been established.
